newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia heads for copper output rise - ABARE.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia heads for copper output rise - ABARE.

text.p: The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said on Tuesday that Australia remained on track to produce about 10 percent more mined copper in 1996/97 (July/June) than in 1995/96.

In 1997/98, domestic copper mine output should climb a further 13 percent as production at larger existing operations was maintained and new and expanded mine output came on stream, the government forecasting agency said.
Australia is forecast to produce a total of 530,000 tonnes of mined copper (331,000 tonnes refined) in 1996/97 and 600,000 tonnes (393,000 tonnes refined) in the following fiscal year, ABARE said.
The increase in refined copper output will mainly be a result of the planned expansion of the Townsville, Queensland refinery owned by MIM Holdings Ltd.

MIM is increasing annual production capacity at the refinery to 250,000 tonnes from the current 175,000 tonnes, mainly to accommodate new supplies of concentrates coming from an expansion of its Mount Isa mine and the Ernest Henry joint

Australian export earnings are forecast to increase 14 percent in 1996/97 and a further seven percent in 1997/98, with substantially higher export volumes of both concentrates and refined metal expected to more than offset the effects on earnings of forecast lower world prices, ABARE said.

An anticipated rise in world copper inventories later this year is forecast to weigh on international prices, which should decline on average one percent from 1996 to around US$2,270 a tonne, ABARE said.

Following growth of around 2.4 percent in calendar 1996, world copper consumption is forecast to increase 3.5 percent this year to 12.52 million tonnes against production of 13.08 million tonnes, ABARE said.
